message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The girl has a cystic swelling in the midline of the neck that moves upwards on protrusion of the tongue, which is indicative of a thyroglossal duct cyst. Ultrasonography of the neck is the most appropriate next step to confirm the diagnosis and plan management. Excision of the cyst with track and hyoid bone may be necessary, but a diagnosis with ultrasonography is required first. CT scan of the neck is not the first-line diagnostic test for thyroglossal duct cyst. Excision of the cyst without a confirmed diagnosis may lead to unnecessary surgery.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the cystic, midline swelling that moves upwards on protrusion of the tongue suggests a thyroglossal duct cyst. Ultrasonography of the neck can confirm the diagnosis and determine if excision of the cyst is necessary. CT scan is not the first-line imaging study for evaluating thyroglossal duct cysts. Excision of the cyst, track and hyoid bone is not necessary unless the cyst is large or symptomatic. Excision of the cyst alone may not address the underlying thyroglossal duct abnormality, which may lead to recurrence.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Based on the presented case history and physical examination findings, the most likely diagnosis is thyroglossal duct cyst. Ultrasonography of the neck is the most appropriate next step in management as it will help to confirm the diagnosis and assess the size, location, and relationship of the cyst to surrounding structures. Excision of the cyst is the definitive treatment, but it should only be performed after confirmation of the diagnosis and proper evaluation of the surrounding structures. Excision of the cyst, track and hyoid bone is an outdated and unnecessary procedure. CT scan of the neck may provide additional information but is not the initial test of choice.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The nontender swelling in the midline of the neck moving upwards on protrusion of the tongue suggests thyroglossal duct cyst. Ultrasonography of the neck can confirm the diagnosis and evaluate the extent of the cyst before surgical management. Excision of the cyst with or without the track and hyoid bone can be considered after confirmation of the diagnosis. CT scan is not necessary at this stage.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation suggests a thyroglossal duct cyst, which is usually located in the midline of the neck and moves upwards on protrusion of the tongue. Ultrasonography is the most appropriate next step in management to further evaluate the cyst before surgical intervention. Excision of the cyst is the ultimate treatment, but an imaging study should be done first. Option A (excision of the cyst, track, and hyoid bone) is only appropriate in cases of recurrent thyroglossal duct cysts or when cancer is suspected. CT scan of the neck is not necessary for the diagnosis of a thyroglossal duct cyst.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The midline cystic swelling, which moves upwards on protrusion of the tongue, suggests a thyroglossal duct cyst. Ultrasonography is the most appropriate next step in management. Excision of the cyst, track and hyoid bone is not necessary unless it’s a complicated presentation, and CT scan is not as sensitive as ultrasonography in identifying cystic lesions. Excision of the cyst alone may lead to recurrence.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The midline location, cystic nature, and movement on protrusion of the tongue suggests a thyroglossal duct cyst. The most appropriate next step is ultrasonography to confirm the diagnosis and guide further management. Excision of the cyst, with or without the track and hyoid bone, is the recommended definitive treatment. CT scan is not necessary in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The midline location of the neck swelling and its ability to move upwards on protrusion of the tongue suggest a thyroglossal duct cyst. Ultrasonography of the neck would be the most appropriate next step to evaluate the size and extent of the cyst before deciding on excision. CT scan would be helpful if there is suspicion of malignancy, but is not necessary in this case. Excision of the cyst alone without addressing the track and hyoid bone could lead to recurrence of the cyst.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The midline location of the swelling and its ability to move upwards on protrusion of the tongue suggest a thyroglossal duct cyst. Ultrasonography of the neck is the most appropriate next step in management to confirm the diagnosis and determine the extent of the cyst before planning for excision. Options A and D both involve excision but it’s important to confirm the diagnosis first. CT scan is less sensitive than ultrasonography for this type of cyst.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, ultrasonography of the neck is the most appropriate next step in management to confirm the diagnosis of a thyroglossal duct cyst. Excision of the cyst can follow based on imaging findings. Excision of the cyst with the track and hyoid bone is not necessary unless malignancy is suspected, which is not mentioned in the question stem. CT scan is not the first-line imaging modality for this condition.
